Summary: The Maxwell equation was discovered by C. M. Cunningham and B. J. Bateman a century ago. To quantize the Maxwell field and due to gauge freedom, a gauge fixing condition is necessary. The Lorenz gauge is usually used, which breaks the @xmath0 invariance. Since such a symmetry might lack physical meaning, its breaking does not bother many people. The purpose of the present paper is to demonstrate the benefits of keeping this fundamental symmetry when quantizing the Maxwell field in conformally flat spaces (CFS). The starting point is the following: a. Classical @xmath0-invariant field cannot distinguish between two CFSs locally. b. Why not maintain the @xmath0-invariance during the quantization process in a CFS? c. Doing so, a free field living in a CFS might behave like in a flat space and the corresponding wightman two-point functions can be related to their minkowski counterparts. The work confirms this assertion in the special case of the Maxwell field in de Sitter space.

During the past few years, research in wireless ad-hoc networks and wireless sensor networks (WSNS) has escalated. The IEEE 802.15.4 standard is targeted for wireless body area networks (WBANS), which requires low power and low data rate applications. The invasive computing concept is used to describe the future of computing and communications. Personal and business domains are densely populated with sensors. One area of increasing interest is the adaptation of technology to operate in and around human body. Many other potential applications like medical sensing control, wearable computing, and location identification are based on wireless body area networks (WBANS). Main aim of the IEEE 802.15.4 standard is to provide a low-cost, low power, and reliable protocol for wireless monitoring of patient health. This standard defines physical layer and MAC sub layer. Three distinct frequency bands are supported in this standard. However, 2.4 GHz band is more important. This frequency range is same as IEEE 802.11b/g and Bluetooth. The paper focuses on analysis of the IEEE 802.15.4 standard with non-beacon enabled mode configured in a star topology. We also consider that sensor nodes are using CSMA/CA protocol to access channel data. In literature, beacon enabled mode is used with slotted CSMA/CA for different network settings. In [1], performance analysis of IEEE 802.15.4 low power and low data rate wireless standard in WBANS is done. Authors consider a star topology at 2.4 GHz with up to 10 body implanted sensors. Long-term power consumption of devices is the main aim of their analysis. However, authors do not analyze their study for different data rates. An analytical model for non-beacon enabled mode of the IEEE 802.15.4 medium access control (MAC) protocol is provided in [2]. Nodes use un-slotted CSMA/CA operation for channel access and packet transmission. Two main variables needed for channel access algorithm are back-off exponent (be) and number of back-offs (nb). Authors perform mathematical modeling for the evaluation statistical distribution of traffic generated by nodes. This mathematical model allows evaluating an optimum size packet so that success probability of transmission is maximize. However, authors do not analyze different MAC parameters with varying data rates. Authors carry out an extensive analysis based on simulations and real measurements to investigate the unreliability in the IEEE 802.15

<summary>Understanding Phase Transitions: From Macroscopic to Microscopic</summary>

Phase transitions are pivotal in understanding the behavior of physical systems, particularly in condensed matter physics, where they play a crucial role in the phase diagram of materials. The most dramatic changes in macroscopic properties occur at phase transitions, often involving symmetry breaking. The theory of such phase transitions was formulated by Landau as a phenomenological model, later developed from microscopic principles using the renormalization group. One can identify phases by knowledge of an order parameter, which is zero in the disordered phase and nonzero in the ordered phase. In many known models, the order parameter can only be defined in a complicated non-local way. These systems include topological states like topological insulators, quantum spin Hall states, and quantum spin liquids. Therefore, we need to develop new methods to identify parameters capable of describing phase transitions. Such methods might be borrowed from machine learning. Since the 1990s, this field has undergone major changes with the development of powerful computers and artificial neural networks. It has been shown that such neural networks can approximate every function under mild assumptions. They quickly found applications in image classification, speech recognition, natural language understanding, and predicting from high-dimensional data. Furthermore, they began to outperform other algorithms on these tasks. In the last years, physicists started to employ machine learning techniques. Most of the tasks were tackled by supervised learning algorithms or with the help of reinforcement learning. supervised learning means one is given labeled training data from which the algorithm learns to assign labels to data points. After successful training, it can then predict the labels of previously unseen data with high accuracy. In addition to supervised learning, there are unsupervised learning algorithms which can find structure in unlabeled data. They can also classify data into clusters, which are however unlabelled. It is already possible to employ unsupervised learning techniques to reproduce Monte Carlo-sampled states of the Ising model. Phase transitions were found in unsupervised manner using principal component analysis. We transition from principal component analysis to variational autoencoders, and finally test how the latter handles different physical models. Our algorithms are able to find a low-dimensional latent representation of the physical system which coincides with the correct order parameter. The decoder network reconstructs the encoded configuration from its latent representation. We find that the reconstruction is more accurate in the ordered phase, which suggests the use of the reconstruction error as a universal identifier for phase transitions. In contrast, physicists use unsupervised learning to determine phase

Summary 1: Turbulence is a complex phenomenon with unpredictable behavior of velocity fields, which can be influenced by multiple degrees of freedom and nonlinearity in fluid systems. The scale transformation between QT and sst spectra is discussed, and the Kolmogorov type dimensional scaling analysis is used to confirm the Kolmogorov spectrum in sst. The numerical results of sst in a spin-1 ferromagnetic spinor BEC show that the Kolmogorov spectrum appears in the spectrum of superflow kinetic energy and spin-dependent interaction energy. 1. The kondo lattice model (klm) describes localized magnetic moments of spin, coupled antiferromagnetically via exchange interaction to a metallic host of mobile conduction electrons.

Modern Accelerator-Based Neutrino Oscillation Experiments Require Good Control over Intermediate-Energy Neutrino-Nucleus Scattering Cross Sections The analysis of modern accelerator-based neutrino oscillation experiments requires good control over the intermediate-energy neutrino-nucleus scattering cross section. In particular, the importance of multi-nucleon events has been suggested in many calculations of charge-changing quasielastic cross sections. The contribution of two-particle-two-hole (2p-2h) excitations is now thought to be essential for a proper description of data on neutrino experiments with accelerators. Thus, a growing interest has arisen in including 2p-2h models into the Monte Carlo event generators used by the neutrino collaborations. The only 2p-2h model implemented up to date in some of the Monte Carlo neutrino event generators corresponds to the ific valence model, which has been incorporated in genie. There are also plans to incorporate the lyon model in genie, while phenomenological approaches like the effective transverse enhancement model of xw are implemented, for instance, in nuwro generator. One of the main problems to implementing the 2p-2h models is the high computational time. This is due to the large number of nested integrals involved in the evaluation of the inclusive hadronic tensor with sums over the final 2p-2h states. To speed up the calculations, several approximations can be made, such as choosing an average momentum for the nucleons in the local fermi gas, neglecting the exchange matrix elements, or reducing the number of integrations to two nested integrals by performing a non-relativistic expansion of the current operators. The latter approach is only useful for some pieces of the elementary 2p-2h response. 1. The term "stochastic resonance" was introduced in the early 1980s.
2. Stochastic resonance is the effect of nonmonotone dependence of the response of a system on the noise when this noise is added to a periodic input signal.
3. An extensive review on stochastic resonance and its presence in different fields of applications can be found in @xcite.
4. Following @xcite, as stochastic resonance we intend the phenomenon in which the transmission of a signal can be improved (in terms of statistical quantities) by the addition of noise.
5. The problem is to estimate a signal @xmath4 transmitted through a channel.
6. This signal has to be detected by a receiver that can reveal signals louder than a threshold @xmath1.
7. If @xmath2 is bounded from above by @xmath1, the signal is not observable and the problem has not a solution.
8. But, if some noise @xmath3 is added to the signal, the perturbed signal @xmath4 may be observable and inference can be done on @xmath2.
9. Too few noise is not sufficient to give good estimates and too much noise deteriorates excessively the signal.
10. The optimal in some sense level of the noise will be called stochastic resonance in this framework.
11. Usually, the criterion applied to measure optimality of estimators are the shannon mutual information or the kullback divergence.
12. More recently, the fisher information quantity have been also proposed (see @xcite and @xcite).
13. Here we are concerned with the fisher information quantity.
14. It happens that this quantity, as a function of the noise, can be maximized for certain noise structures.
15. If there is only one global maximum, the corresponding noise level is the value for which we have stochastic resonance, if several local maxima are present, the phenomenon is called stochastic multi-resonance.

10. The study concludes that the narrow emission lines in the bowen region are likely to be due to the irradiated surface of the secondary star.

Summary 1: The axial anomaly represents a fundamental issue for understanding the basic aspects of quantum field theory, with its resolution being a key step in the derivation of the chiral limit and the anomalous breaking of the chiral symmetry.
Summary 2: The resolution of the axial anomaly is essential for the understanding of the chiral limit and the anomalous breaking of the chiral symmetry, as it allows for the cancellation of mass singularities in the decay rates of radiative pions and @xmath1 decays, and provides a mechanism for the cancellation of collinear singularities in the radiative pion decay.

1. The text discusses the importance of salient object detection in visual saliency modeling and salient object detection models.
2. It highlights the challenges in creating a benchmark dataset for salient object detection and the need for more diverse datasets.
3. The authors propose a simple baseline salient object detection model to assess the accuracy of saliency detection models.
4. The model is compared to existing models and found to be effective in challenging scenes.
5. The authors discuss the importance of explicit human saliency judgments in determining the most salient object.
6. They argue that the literature has focused on avoiding incorrectly segmenting the object region, leading to low performance.
7. The authors suggest that the most salient object in a scene is the one that attracts the majority of fixations.
8. They identify two main reasons for model performance drop on the judd-a dataset: the first is that the literature has focused on avoiding incorrectly segmenting the object region, while the second is that the salient object is not the most salient one.
9. The text concludes by emphasizing the importance of more elaborate analysis of interplay between saliency detection, fixation prediction, and object proposal generation, and by suggesting that the proposed model can be used as a baseline for future benchmarking.

Summary:
The nucleon in the low-energy regime is described by a unified chiral interaction that includes both the short-range interaction (giving rise to the spin-singlet states) and the long-range Yukawa interaction (giving rise to the spin-singlet states). The short-range interaction is crucial for the nucleon's stability and is related to the fermi nature of constituent quarks and the specific interactions between them. The chiral interaction is responsible for the short-range repulsion in the nucleon, which is also responsible for the hyperfine splittings in baryon spectroscopy. The chiral interaction is also responsible for the long-range attraction in the nucleon, which is implied by the Yukawa part of the pion-exchange and correlated two-pion exchanges. The chiral interaction is also responsible for the tensor and spin-orbit forces, which come from the pseudoscalar- and vector-exchange Yukawa tails. The chiral interaction is also responsible for the necessary effective repulsion in the dominant configuration of the chiral interaction, which is related to the energy ballance. The chiral interaction is also responsible for the tensor and spin-orbit forces, which come from the pseudoscalar- and vector-exchange Yukawa tails. Summary 1: The invention pertains to a sol-gel process for synthesizing calcium phosphate, in particular, hydroxyapatite (HA), thin film coatings on implantable medical devices. The process allows the HA to be obtained in a crystallized form, at a relatively low temperature, i.e., approximately 350-500° C. This is an unexpectedly low crystallization temperature for HA sol-gel synthesis. The process provides excellent chemical and physical homogeneity, and bonding strength of HA coatings to substrates. The low process temperature avoids substrate metal degradation due to thermally-induced phase transformation, microstructure deterioration, or oxidation.  
Summary 2: The invention in one embodiment is directed to a sol-gel process for preparing calcium phosphate, such as hydroxyapatite, which comprises: (a) hydrolysing a phosphor precursor in a water or alcohol based medium; (b) adding a calcium salt precursor to the medium after the phosphite has been hydrolyzed to obtain a calcium phosphate gel such as a hydroxyapatite gel; (c) depositing the gel on the surface of an implantable medical device; and (d) calcining the calcium phosphate, such as hydroxyapatite, at a suitable elevated temperature and for pre-determined time to achieve desired crystallinity, bonding and porosity characteristics for the coating on the device. The deposition of the gel can be done by any number of methods, such as aero-sol deposition, dip-coating, spin-coating, electrophoretic deposition.

1. The present invention provides a fabricated implantable nerve guidance conduit (NGC) that combines a spiral structured porous sheet with integrated spiral structured porous sheets decorated with surface channels and electrospun fibers. The NGCs are designed to enhance nerve regeneration and neurite extension by providing a highly aligned surface/volume ratio, improved mechanical properties, and stable aligned fibrous layers.

2. The NGCs are tunable in terms of size and length, with the length and outer diameter dependent on the size of the spiral-wound sheet. The NGCs are tunable in terms of mechanical properties, with the Young's modulus, tensile strength, and tensile properties ranging from 0.262 to 0.7625 MPa.

3. Schwann cells are used as a model for evaluating cellular response on the fiber-based spiral NGCs. The NGCs show significantly greater cell proliferation than autografts and T-S-AF groups, indicating enhanced nerve regeneration.

4. The NGCs are tested in a rat sciatic nerve defect to evaluate their effect on peripheral nerve regeneration through porous spiral NGCs. The recovery of motor function is assessed using a walking track, with significant improvements in the autograft group.

5. The NGCs are evaluated for their functional recovery through electrophysiological assessment. The results show that the NGCs can accelerate muscle reinnervation compared to autografts.

6. The NGCs are characterized by their total neural tissue coverage, muscle weight ratio, muscle fiber diameter, and fiber coverage per cross section. The autograft group shows a significant difference in these parameters compared to the other groups.

7. The NGCs are evaluated for their potential to prevent muscle atrophy and the effect of autograft. The surface channels and aligned fibers provide good topographical cues for nerve regeneration, allowing faster nerve regeneration compared to single lumen NGCs.

1. The invention relates to seat base support assemblies for furniture or the like, including sinuous spring bands, wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, or flexible steel bands.

4. The invention includes two related forms of rail connectors, including a pre-stressed, close wound coil spring with attachment arms and a pre-stressed, cantilever spring configuration.

1. The present invention is a noninvasive esophageal displacement electrode that enables the distal end of the electrode to displace angularly within the stomach and subsequently be pulled back out of the esophagus, or alternatively, further angularly displaced upwardly into pressurized contact with the stomach wall to place the electrode in closer proximity to the heart ventricle.
2. The electrode includes a semi rigid plastic tube with an electrode on the distal end, which is crimped to form a hinge at the distal region of the tube. The tube is connected to a control mechanism that allows the user to cause the last couple of inches of the distal end of the tube to bend back on itself approximately 135 degrees from its original position.
3. The control mechanism includes a sleeve with a slide that can be moved to the right to cause the pin to move downwardly in the tube, thereby placing the electrode in proximity to the upper stomach wall near the heart ventricle.
4. The electrode is used in a pacing mechanism as shown in U.S. Pat. No. 4,735,206, supra, and is capable of being inserted into the esophagus either through the mouth or the nasal passage to a depth sufficient to enable displacement of the tube's distal end 12 to approximately 135 degrees from its straighten or insertion position as shown in FIG. 3.
5. The present invention provides a very convenient means of enabling an operator to place the esophageal stomach displacement electrode very close to the heart or other organ by means of a noninvasive procedure and thereby reduce the energy required to carry out the particular procedure such as pacing or defibrillation upon the patient.

Summary 1: The game is a board game with a lake theme, where players move tokens across a continuous path to acquire lake areas, boats, dams, and marinas. Players can purchase tokens for rent, and if unable to meet obligations, they are declared bankrupt and must quit the game. The game involves rolling dice to determine movement of tokens and paying rent to the Bank. Players can also sell, transfer, or mortgage property to raise scrip to satisfy rent payments.

Summary:
1. The invention provides a device and method for treating and regenerating tissues, covering a wound, combining liquid fluid supply and suction, comprising a pole, a rest, said rest being movable in vertical directions along said pole and having a clamp for securing said rest at a height corresponding to the height of the tissue, at least one fluid reservoir placed on said rest, connected to the tissue, and means for controlling the fluid supply and suction.
2. The invention further comprises a restricting means preventing free fluid flow, a means to prevent ingress of air through said supply port in connection with said fluid administration, and a drainage port.
3. The invention also includes a method for treating and regenerating tissues allowing administration of a restricted amount of fluid to the supply port of an occlusively applied porous dressing pad during exposure of said pad to continuous suctioning through a separate drainage port, comprising: applying continuous suction to the drainage port in the range between 30 and 200 mmHg; applying an injection needle airtightly to a syringe or fluid bag filled with saline or drug solution; avoiding a fluid bag hydrostatic load; perforating said supply port elastic injection membrane with the needle during ongoing suction at the drainage port of said dressing pad; injecting the content of the syringe into the dressing pad in 1-5 minutes during ongoing suctioning at said drainage port; stopping the injection once injected fluid becomes visible through the suction tube wall as it exits the drainage port of the dressing pad; and withdrawing the said needle from the elastic membrane.

Summary:
The present invention describes a biological oil composition, formulations, and methods for preventing or treating cardiovascular disease. The oil composition comprises copepod oil and EPA/DHA, and the formulations include the oil composition. The oil composition exhibits significant effects on blood cholesterol levels and atherosclerotic plaque formation. The results show that the copepod oil of the present invention has a notable difference in biological effects compared to EPA and DHA used in the same concentration. The results also demonstrate that the copepod oil of the present invention has a pronounced anti-atherosclerotic effect, reducing atherosclerotic plaque formation and lowering blood cholesterol levels.

1. Polyelectrolyte complexes show properties that meet the profile of requirements for biocompatible polymers and can be adapted to meet various pharmaceutical applications.
2. Microparticles composed of polyelectrolyte complexes can be prepared in average particle sizes from a few nanometers to a few hundred micrometers.
3. The incorporation of an active substance in the polyelectrolyte complex particles/colloids can be carried out in at least four ways: entrapment, absorption, precipitation, or incorporation as a partner in the polyelectrolyte complex.
4. The cytostatic daunorubicin and polyacid xylan polysulfate produce macroparticles with sustained release of the cytostatic in buffer solution or biological systems.
5. The polyelectrolyte complex microparticles can be used as air-containing echogenic contrast agents for ultrasonic diagnosis.
6. The polyelectrolyte complex microparticles are outstandingly suitable as air-containing echogenic contrast agents for ultrasonic diagnosis.
7. The polyelectrolyte complex microparticles can be converted into microparticulate forms for injection or administration.
8. The polyelectrolyte complex microparticles can be used as air-containing echogenic contrast agents for ultrasonic diagnosis.

<summary>Several objects and advantages of the present invention are:

1. The invention eliminates the need for manual unclamping of the golf ball and tee, allowing the golfer to retrieve the tee without bending over.
2. The device is lightweight, portable, and does not require a substantial amount of space in a golf bag.
3. It can be used to retrieve golf tees from the ground even if they are in a horizontal orientation.
4. The device can be used to tee up a golf ball from a standing position without the cumbersome use of large prior mechanisms.
5. It allows a golfer to easily tee up a golf ball without bending over.
6. It permits a golfer to easily retrieve a golf tee without bending over whether or not the tee came out of the ground while hitting the ball.
7. It has the additional advantages in that it permits a golf club to be utilized as the handle reducing the weight and size of the device.
8. It is very simple to use with no cumbersome controls to release the tee and ball.
9. It can easily and nonintrusively be clipped onto a golfer's apparel while hitting the ball.
10. It can easily be attached to a golf bag.</summary>

2. The present disclosure relates to a person support apparatus, such as a bed and with a mechanism suitable for adjusting the height and orientation of a patient support frame forming part of that bed.
3. The patient support frame is supported on a deck support or intermediate frame and the deck support frame is provided with a mechanism for adjusting the height of the deck and hence the height of the support surface above the floor on which the apparatus is located, and to control the orientation or inclination of the deck and hence the patient support surface relative to the floor.
4. The mechanism includes a guide element arranged on its side (i.e., with its open side extending in a vertical direction) and arranged around the outside of longitudinal elements having a rectangular cross-section. This arrangement results in a deck support frame which is robust and stable and can accommodate the changes in geometry necessary for movement or adjustment between the horizontal, Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions.
5. Some embodiments of the channel and roller mechanism change the height of a patient support deck by pivoting one or more leg assemblies relative to the under surface of the patient support frame.
6. Features of some illustrative embodiments include the following: 
   - Lower part count than known systems and are therefore likely to be both cheaper and more robust.
   - Opening of the channel carrying the guide elements or rollers faces the floor. This means that dirt is less likely to enter it and interfere with the mechanism.
   - Any dirt that enters will not be visible in normal use.
   - The leg assembly works vertically within the channel edges and a reduced force is therefore necessary to lift the patient support frame especially from the low position where the leg assemblies suspend a narrow angle relative to the underside of the patient support frame.
   - Features described in relation to one aspect and/or embodiment of the present disclosure may equally be applied to other embodiments and/or aspects of the present disclosure.

The invention relates to a skin reflectance measuring apparatus. The apparatus comprises a probe with an aperture for light transmission, a flexible connection in fiber optics for transmitting light, and a measuring device with light emitting means and receiving means. The light emitting means is optically coupled to a second end of the first conductor, and the light receiving means is optically coupled to a second end of the second conductor to produce a first signal representing the specular reflection and a second signal representing the diffuse reflection. The processing means is connected to the light emitting and receiving means and includes correcting means to compensate for variations in the emitted light and ambient light, producing a relative reflectance signal from the measured values of specular reflection and diffuse reflection. The display device receives the reflectance signal to indicate the amplitude of the signal. The apparatus is particularly adapted for measuring the reflectance of the skin.

2. The apparatus comprises a mouthpiece with upper and lower channel members that fit over the upper and lower teeth, respectively, and fit snugly against the respective gums.
3. The apparatus includes a first or outer membrane extending from the uppermost part of the upper channel member downward to the lowermost part of the lower channel member.
4. The apparatus includes a second or inner membrane extending from the uppermost part of the upper channel member downward to the lowermost part of the lower channel member.
5. The apparatus includes bite blocks located in both the upper and lower channel members, with three bite blocks provided in total.

1. The present invention relates to a needle for threading straps of implants through pelvic tissues, including anterior and posterior implants, to facilitate surgical anchoring and reconstruction of pelvic floor structures.
2. The invention includes a needle with a trap for trapping straps, a tip for threading straps, and a mechanism for releasing the trap. The mechanism is driven from the accessible side of the tissue, allowing return of the tip to the accessible side while abandoning the strap at the threaded point, thus performing threading from the accessible side.

4. The invention provides a reliable anchoring mechanism for implants, reducing the need for additional perforations and minimizing surgical access, making it suitable for reconstructive surgeries on pelvic floor structures.

<summary>Fasteners for Album Fasteners</summary>

1. Fasteners for Album Fasteners: The invention provides releasable fasteners for album covers, including front and back covers and removable pages between them. The fasteners consist of strap anchors, which are attached to the front and back covers via strap, and a strap that passes through aligned apertures in the covers and album pages. The strap is snap-locked into the channel by snapping engagement beneath locking lips at the base of the channel, and the base of the channel and opposing surface of the strap are engaged to prevent longitudinal displacement of the strap within the channel when its in its engaged position beneath the lips. The strap enters into the channel via an aperture in the base of the channel and that aperture is bordered by a projection adapted to extend into the adjacent hole in the cover to ensure correct location between the strap anchor and the cover. The strap is of variable length and adjustable in length to accommodate album thickness.

2. Strap Anchors: Strap anchors are moulded in a plastics material and are attached to the front and back covers of the album by adhesive tape. The aperture in the base of the channel is aligned with a hole in the adjacent cover for passage of the strap through the channel. Positive alignment is achieved between the aperture and the hole in the adjacent cover by lugs projecting from the base of the channel at opposite sides of the aperture to engage in the hole in the adjacent cover.

3. Strap: The strap is of variable length and adjustable in length to accommodate album thickness. It passes through the album from the front to the back and is of semi-rigid plastics material. The exposed end portion of the strap is a snap lock into the channel by being pushed into the channel from its open side facing the base, the strap locking beneath pairs of opposed locking lips at opposite sides of the channel. The end of the strap will project beyond the channel by a variable distance depending on the thickness of the album and can be easily be grasped to permit the strap to be disengaged from the channel by pulling the strap away from the base of the channel past the lips.

4. Strap Anchors: Strap anchors are moulded in a suitable plastics material and can be attached to the front and back covers of the album by adhesive such as an adhesive tape. The aperture in the base of the channel is aligned with a hole in the adjacent cover for passage of the strap through the channel. Positive alignment is achieved between the aperture and the hole in the adjacent cover by lugs

Summary 1: The present invention provides a sulky construction that is lightweight, easy to assemble, and has a stable structure. It is designed to be manufactured of light metal and other lightweight materials, and it is easy to store and transport. The sulky is also color-coded and has an inexpensive and individual color display system for end users. The sulky is easy to assemble by a user himself, and it is assembled using ordinary hand tools. The sulky is also designed to be colored by applying color tapes in all recesses of the profiles, which leads to an inexpensive and individual color display system.

<summary>Summary of the Present Invention</summary>
The present invention provides a method for installing flat, uncontoured glass panels in curved window openings of vehicles, including the use of flat glass that is not pre-contoured or tempered. The method involves placing the glass panel within a curved window bay, securing it against the reveal molding, and applying a continuous bead of adhesive sealant into the space between the edge of the glass panel and the window opening. The sealant is cured to permanently hold the glass in place within the window opening. The invention also includes a flexible reveal molding that can be used as a straight member without bending or distortion. The flexible reveal molding is sufficient to hold the glass panel securely in place until the adhesive cures. The flexible reveal molding is also sufficient to allow the adhesive to cure and set the glass panel permanently in place.

<summary>Summary of the Packaging Machine with Enhanced Design</summary>

1. The packaging machine in the disclosed disclosure is a deep-drawing packaging machine that includes a rotating shaft arranged in the production direction of the machine. The shaft and each of the movable tool members of various work stations have provided between them at least one transfer mechanism for converting the rotational movement of the shaft into the movement required to operate the respective tool member. This transfer mechanism is rendered robust and independent of high wear components, such as belts, and is capable of transferring forces effectively through a cam mechanism. The shaft is driven alternately in different directions of rotation, allowing for the simultaneous operation of different work stations.

2. The packaging machine is provided with a frame that supports the shaft and is arranged horizontally between two conveying planes. The frame comprises a plurality of lateral longitudinal bars and cross bars, which are oriented in the production direction of the machine. The frame is designed to be compact and provide adequate support for the shaft, preventing torsional forces within the shaft.

3. The shaft is supported in a plurality of cross bars of the frame, which are arranged in a uniform pattern for providing a uniform frame for all work stations. The shaft is also arranged centrally within the packaging machine, facilitating easy installation and maintenance.

4. The transfer mechanisms for the shaft are arranged symmetrically with respect to the shaft, extending at the same distance from the shaft located between them. This ensures that the shaft acts as a "main shaft" controlling the movements of the movable tool members of different work stations.

5. The packaging machine is equipped with a forming station, a sealing station, and a separating station, each of which includes a forming tool, a sealing tool top, and a sealing tool bottom, respectively. The forming tool is moved by the shaft, and the sealing tool top and bottom are moved by the transfer mechanisms. The sealing tool top is capable of lifting the sealing knife, while the sealing tool bottom is capable of cutting through the web-shaped packaging material.

<summary>1. The invention is based on a generic hydraulic unit for a vehicle brake system. The hydraulic unit has at least one pump that has a piston, and the piston is indirectly drivable by an electric motor via an eccentric that is rotatable inside an eccentric chamber. Because it cannot be precluded that the moving piston may entrain pressure fluid into the eccentric chamber through a sealing ring or the like on the occasion of pump operation, a conduit extends downward from the eccentric chamber and opens to the atmosphere through a housing block that receives the at least one pump; a check valve that can open toward the atmosphere is built into the conduit. Pressure fluid that has been entrained into the eccentric chamber and drips from the piston enters the conduit and stresses the check valve, causing it to open, and finally flows out of the housing block. As a result, filling of the eccentric chamber with pressure fluid is averted, so that pressure fluid remains far away from the electric motor, or in other words does not penetrate the electric motor and impair the operability thereof. 2. In a hydraulic unit known from International Patent Disclosure WO 96/13416, the electric motor is located above an eccentric chamber, in which the eccentric acting on at least one piston of a pump is rotatable. As an additional provision, the central venting point may have a check valve mentioned in this aforementioned patent disclosure. This allows the system to be used with various types of vehicles, with modifications to the circuit. The system includes an electro-optic reflective element that assumes a partial reflectance level in response to a drive signal. <summary>Partition and Bulkhead Systems for Multi-temperature Transport</summary>  
The present invention includes improved partition systems that allow for the division of cargo areas into different temperature zones. These systems are particularly useful for multi-temperature transport, where refrigerated trailers, railcars, or containers are used to transport perishable goods. The systems consist of modular wall sections that can be slidably attached to the ceiling of the trailer or body, allowing for the division of the cargo space into different temperature zones. The panels can be independently attached to the rails, allowing for the movement of the bulkhead to define different cargo areas. The systems also include sliding mechanisms that allow the bulkhead to be raised and lowered, facilitating the movement of the bulkhead to maintain different temperature zones. The systems also include locking mechanisms that prevent the bulkhead from being removed or reinstalled, ensuring the proper functioning of the system.

<summary>Summary of the Invention</summary> The inventor has designed a novel sanitizable rotary valve that combines elements previously found in the valve art but adds a unique feature of partial (sealed) separation of the rotor-stator faces to allow flushing across the process fluid-contacting surfaces. This partial separation would normally result in sanitizing fluid leaking out of the valve, leading to non-aseptic operation, but a novel diaphragm-like elastomeric seal has been invented which functions to both seal the two faces together in normal use and retain sanitizing process fluids when the faces are partially separated for cleaning. This design allows the unique sanitary operation of the valve that is disclosed herein, enabling the ability to sanitize in place (SIP) without disassembling the valve. Additionally, the invention provides a sliding multi-port diaphragm valve with at least two inner surfaces, including a rotor with a stator-facing surface and a diaphragm with a dynamic wipe sealing lip, which allows periodic sanitization and cleaning of the port sealing faces of the stator and rotor without loss of fluid to the outside. The invention also provides an insert molding process for forming in place a rotary valve diaphragm seal, including the steps of affixing a mold base to the rotor, capping ports with flange-forming plugs, and injecting the rotor with an elastomer suitable for forming a diaphragm seal. The invention also provides a multi-port sliding valve with a linear slider, a stator with a plurality of connection ports and associated channels in liquid communication with external fluid sources and separation means, and orthogonal separation means for partially separating the slider body from the stator body to allow flushing of sanitizing fluid across the stator face without loss of fluid to the outside. The invention also provides a simple and reliable elastomeric means of ensuring sealing of all ports in a slider valve which is tolerant of imperfect flatness or parallelism of the stator or slider sealing faces, which maintains an acceptable sealing integrity over a useful life at least equal to that of typical chromatographic beds used for pharmaceutical manufacturing purification processes.

<summary>Enhanced Gas-Liquid Contacting Tray Assembly and Method</summary>  
The present invention provides an improved tray valve assembly for a gas-liquid contacting tray, including a circular disc with a first and second leg disposed in a downwardly inclined orientation. The valve assembly includes a valve cover mounted on the disc, with the valve cover having a first leg disposed to intercept the liquid flow across the tray and a second leg disposed along a line perpendicular to the downcomer. The valve assembly further includes means for selectively biasing the rear region of the valve cover upwardly against the liquid flow for facilitating initial, directionalized vapor flow therethrough. The valve assembly also includes a circular disc mounted above the active tray area, with the disc having first and second legs in support thereof, the first leg wider than the second leg for directing flow therearound. The valve aperture is circular in shape and the valve legs are disposed in slotted regions disposed outwardly of the circular aperture to prevent the rotation of the valve plate for maintaining the orientation of the valve leg relative to the tray. The biasing means comprises a detent portion formed on the cover of the valve for preventing the surface thereof from resting flush against the tray surface. This design facilitates the initial passage of vapor through the valve. The valves are also comprised of circular discs mounted in and above circular apertures formed in the active tray area. Certain ones of the valves are oriented for the directional thrust of vapor therethrough in a select orientation that is not parallel to the initial flow of liquid thereacross for imparting a directional thrust to the liquid flow. In this manner, the direction of liquid flow can be effected, which further enhances the effectiveness of a raised active inlet area adapted for the discharge of vapor into the liquid coming from a downcomer for passage onto the valve area.

<summary>Advantages of the Fluid Pressure Regulator Assembly</summary>

1. The fluid pressure regulator assembly reduces pressure variances, allowing a more economical regulator to be used.
2. It is inexpensive to manufacture and maintain, making it suitable for a wide range of applications.
3. It is lightweight and portable, making it easy to use in various settings.
4. It reduces the size and cost of a regulator needed to regulate the pressure of a fluid, making it more efficient.
5. It is suitable for use in a variety of applications, including gas grills, underwater breathing apparatuses, and medical applications.
6. It is suitable for use in a variety of applications, including self-contained underwater breathing apparatuses and diving gear.
7. It is suitable for use in a variety of applications, including scuba diving and welding assemblies.

<summary>Overview of the Pallet System</summary>

The invention features a pallet system that supports a load of at least one tray having side supports. The system includes a pallet with at least one pair of parallel guide rails raised above the top surface of the pallet, each pair configured to be straddled by side supports of a tray. The system also includes end stops on the top surface of the pallet, positioned to limit longitudinal movement of a tray loaded on the pallet. The system further includes end plates secured to the stacked trays, with end plates having an inside surface shaped to complement the contours of the tray edges. The system also includes end plates with a raised, parallel guide rail, positioned to support the weight of the trays and interlock adjacent trays. The system allows trays to be slid on and off, and is suitable for automated loading and unloading of trays. The system restricts both lateral and longitudinal movement of items loaded onto the pallet, provides enhanced stability, and allows trays to be slid on and off. The system also features end stops at both ends of the guide rails, which limit the longitudinal movement of the trays parallel to the guide rails. The system is customizable for different loads and sizes, and can be used for various applications, including egg trays.

Summary:

Summary 1: The invention provides methods for synthesizing substituted guanidines using nickel catalysts, particularly nickel in the zero oxidation state. The methods include guanylating amines or pyrrolidines with thioureas or isothioureas in the presence of nickel catalysts. The nickel catalysts are derived from nickel-boride alloys, nickel-phosphide alloys, aluminum-nickel alloys, nickel on kieselguhr, and nickel on silica/alumina. The nickel catalysts are advantageous due to their relatively inexpensive cost and ease of recovery after the guanylation reactions. The nickel catalysts are essentially completely recoverable after the guanylation reactions, allowing them to be reused. The nickel catalysts should be present at a level of less than about 10 molar % nickel, preferably less than about 5 molar % nickel, based upon the total moles of guanylating agent(s) (e.g., isothioureas and/or thioureas) taken as 100%. The nickel catalysts are particularly advantageous due to their relatively inexpensive cost and ease of recovery after the guanylation reactions. 2. The invention also provides an apparatus and method for continuously conducting first an anodic oxidation and then an electrolytic coloring of aluminum strips or wires for forming a colored anodic coating on the aluminum strip or wire.

4. The invention provides an apparatus of continuous electrolytic coloring of aluminum strips or wires comprising a means for continuously supplying an aluminum strip or wire, an anodic oxidation bath for anodizing the aluminum strip or wire and having a cathode disposed therein, an electrolytic coloring bath for electrolytically coloring the anodized aluminum strip or wire, this electrolytic coloring bath containing at least one of a nickel salt, a cobalt salt, a copper salt, a tin salt, and selenious acid and having an anode disposed therein, an electric circuit for connecting the cathode and the anode to a power source and causing the aluminum strip or wire to function as an anode in the anodic oxidation bath and to function as a cathode in the electrolytic coloring bath without connecting the aluminum strip or wire directly to a power source, and a means for passing the aluminum strip or wire continuously and successively through the baths.
5. Summary:
The invention describes a process for producing transgenic plants or plant cells transformed on a chromosome with a DNA sequence of interest and capable of expressing a function of interest from said DNA sequence of interest. The process includes providing plant cells or plants with at least two different vectors, assembling a DNA sequence of interest containing T-DNA border sequences, selecting plants or plant cells expressing said function of interest, and optionally screening for transformed plants or plant cells in which recombination between at least two of said at least two different vectors has occurred. The invention also provides transgenic plants or parts thereof like seeds produced by the process.

<summary>Summary of the Invention</summary>

1. The present invention is directed to a swash plate type compressor for compressing refrigerant gas, comprising a cylinder block with cylinder bores disposed parallel to the axis of the cylinder block, a rotary shaft rotatably mounted within the cylinder block, and an aluminum swash plate fixed to the rotary shaft and having two facial surfaces and an end surface. The facial surfaces have a heat curable, cross-linked coating comprising a polyfluoro elastomer bonded directly to the aluminum, a lubricious additive, and a load bearing additive. The coating on the swash plate permits the use of low silicon alloy aluminum without the need of metal plating or high finish polishing. The coating includes lubricious and load bearing additives to enable the polyfluoro elastomer-based coating to simultaneously provide the necessary durability and low coefficient of friction surface. The fluorocarbon coating is applied to the swash plate in a liquid spray and cured in an oven at an elevated temperature. The swash plate facial surfaces, together with the end surface, may be simultaneously coated. Additionally, the piston shoe may be coated with the fluorocarbon coating to further increase the low friction properties of the compressor. The coating is different from prior swash plate designs having fluororesin coatings by bonding and then cross-linking the fluorocarbon directly to the aluminum. The coating includes lubricious and load bearing additives to enable the polyfluoro elastomer-based coating to simultaneously provide the necessary durability and low coefficient of friction surface. The fluorocarbon coating is applied to the swash plate in a liquid spray and cured in an oven at an elevated temperature. The swash plate facial surfaces, together with the end surface, may be simultaneously coated. Additionally, the piston shoe may be coated with the fluorocarbon coating to further increase the low friction properties of the compressor.</summary>

<summary>Advantages of Organic Anti-Reflective Coatings for Photolithography Processes</summary>  
- The present invention provides novel chemical compounds suitable for use in anti-reflective coatings in photolithography processes for forming submicro-patterns using 193 nm (ArF) and 248 nm (KrF) light beams in the manufacture of semiconductor devices.  
- The polymers of the present invention are designed to facilitate light absorption at wavelengths of 193 nm and 248 nm by having groups that absorb light strongly at both wavelengths.  
- The polymers represented by general formulas 1, 2 and 3 can be prepared in accordance with reaction equations 1, 2 and 3, respectively.  
- The anti-reflective coating composition of the present invention can be prepared by dissolving a polymer of general formula 1, 2 or 3 above in an organic solvent, and subsequently adding one or more compounds selected from Tables 1a and 1b.  
- The organic solvent used for the preparation can be any suitable conventional organic solvent, preferably a solvent selected from the group consisting of ethyl 3-ethoxypropionate, methyl 3-methoxypropionate, cyclohexanone, propylene glycol and methyletheracetate.  
- The polymers comprising the anti-reflective coating of the present invention form a cross-linked structure when they are coated on a wafer and baked at high temperatures through a reaction which opens the ring of the diazonaphthoquinone group in said polymers.  
- The polymers and compositions of the present invention have proven to be excellent organic anti-reflective coating materials during the formation of submicro-patterns in photolithographic processes using 248 nm KrF and 193 nm ArF lasers.  
- The anti-reflective effect provided in accordance with the present invention have also been found to be superior when E-beam, extreme ultraviolet (EUV) light, and ion beam light sources are used instead of an ArF beam.

<summary>1. The invention relates to a white, flame-retardant, UV-resistant, thermoformable, oriented film made from a crystallizable thermoplastic, the thickness of the film being in the range from 10 to 350 μm. The film comprises at least one white pigment and one flame retardant and one UV absorber and has good orientability and thermoformability, and very good optical and mechanical properties, and can be produced cost-effectively.</summary>

1. The invention provides a novel process for producing 143a in an economical, industrially feasible manner, based on continuous gas phase hydrofluorination using heterogeneous catalysis.
2. The process uses 142b and HF as feedstocks, and CrF3.4H2O and Cr/Ni/AlF3 catalysts as catalysts.
3. The process achieves high conversion and selectivity for 143a, with conversion rates and selectivities exceeding 99%.
4. The catalysts are CrF3.4H2O and Cr/Ni/AlF3, and the molar ratio of HF:142b is greater than 1:1.
5. The process is suitable for industrial applications, with a high yield and selectivity for 143a.
6. The process can be carried out at temperatures as low as 100°C, with a high conversion rate.
7. The process can be run under adiabatic conditions, with a reactor temperature as low as 100°C.
8. The process can be carried out using 142b as a feedstock, with 141b and 142b as co-feed.
9. The process can be used to produce 143a at high conversion rates, with selectivity for 143a exceeding 99%.

<summary>Background of the Invention</summary>

Pyrazolotriazoles, such as those described herein, are useful magenta couplers for photographic products. However, they are difficult to synthesize. Only a few synthetic routes are known. One of the preferred synthetic routes involves preparation of the triazolothiadiazines 1 and subsequent desulfurization reaction to give the pyrazolotriazoles 2. The triazolothiadiazines 1 can be prepared in two ways; the first, by reaction of 4-amino-5-mercapto-3-substituted(R)-1,2,4-triazoles (4) with alpha-haloketones, or the second, by reaction of 2-hydrazino-5-substituted-(R')-1,3,4-thiadiazines (5) with acyl halides and subsequent dehydrative ring closure. Both the triazoles 4 and the thiadiazines 5 are readily available from thiocarbohydrazide; ##STR4## The desulfurization of these triazolothiadiazines 1 to the pyrazolotriazoles 2: ##STR5## is effected in two steps; the first, a ring contraction reaction of 1 by heating in acetic anhydride to give 1-acetyl-7-acetylthio-3,6-disubstituted-1H-pyrazolo[5,1-c]-1,2,4-triazoles (6) and, the second, hydrolysis of acetyl groups and desulfurization at the same time with hydrochloric acid to give the desired 2. ##STR6## Although this is the most attractive and practical method for desulfurization among those available, there are several drawbacks in using this as a manufacturing process. The first ring contraction reaction is usually clean and does not render any problem except long reaction time. In fact, the reaction mixture is clean enough to be used in

- The invention provides a method and apparatus for forming fiber mixtures from a plurality of fiber types by sequentially taking, from different fiber lots, a partial quantity which is small with respect to the entire quantity of the mixture.

Summary 1: The present invention provides a method and apparatus for forming bias laid, non-woven fabrics, wherein the yarns in at least two of the layers of fabric are laid at an angle of from 30° to 150° to the long axis of the fabric. The yarns in the various layers are neither knitted, nor woven, but are held together by stitching through the layers, knitting with a loose stitch through the layers, or adhesively bonding threads of the layers at crossing points. The invention is particularly useful for structural purposes, where the traditional knitted or woven fabrics do not provide sufficient strength, even when impregnated with a curable resin system, to provide the necessary uniformity and strength.

Summary 1: The present invention provides a method and apparatus for inserting different weft threads in and through warp sheds in a multiple-color air jet loom, including a source for ejecting air under pressure, subnozzles divided into different groups for producing different additional weft carrying forces, and a control system for controlling the air supply to the subnozzles. The method includes providing different weft carrying forces by varying the interval of time in which air is ejected, and the apparatus includes a weft insertion main nozzle and weft carrying subnozzles for ejecting air under pressure. The control system controls the air supply to the subnozzles based on weft selection signals and air pressure settings.

The present invention provides a bast fibre yarn obtained through spinning bast fibres, and a process of making thereof, in particular, relates to a bast fibre yarn obtained through twice health-preserving bast fibres and blended spinning bast fibres and other fibres, together with a process of making thereof. The present invention also provides a multi-fibre yarn obtained through blended spinning bast fibres and other fibres, and a process of making thereof, which may also have a low end breakage rate.

<summary>1. The present invention provides a method and apparatus for measuring and removing rotational variability from the nip pressure profile of a sensing roll of a nip press, including providing a sensing roll having a working length and a plurality of cross-directional positions disposed along the working length, and positioning pairs of pressure-measuring sensors at each cross-directional position. The method calculates an average pressure measurement utilizing the number of sensors placed at each CD position, and the readings from the four sensors of the embodiments of  FIGS. 7A and 7B  and  FIGS. 10A and 10B  are utilized to produce an average pressure measurement. The embodiment of  FIGS. 8A and 8B  utilizes a pair of sensor measurements at each CD position, and the average pressure measurements at each cross-directional position can then be used to provide a nip pressure profile for the nip press.</summary>

The present invention provides an apparatus for supporting an electrical cord and storing an article, such as a spray starch can or a beverage container. The apparatus includes a releasable clamp for securing the cord to an ironing board, a flexible cord support for supporting the electrical cord, and an article holder for holding an article. The clamp includes a retainer for retaining the flexible cord support on the clamp. The article holder has a lower circular hoop and supports an article such as a can of starch, a spray bottle, a beverage container, or a remote control. The apparatus can be mounted on an ironing board and can be removed from the ironing board when not in use.

1. The invention provides a buttonhole controlling device for a sewing machine, which can be rendered effective regardless of the type of material being sewn to cause buttonhole stitching to close without overlap.
2. The device includes a foot pad that attaches to a presser bar and a travelling assembly with an initial position relative to the foot pad as defined by oppositely acting springs.
3. The travelling assembly moves with work fed during the sewing of a buttonhole and includes a slidable member that may be positioned by a button for which a buttonhole is to be sewn.
4. The device can precisely define the closure point and prevent the formation of an open buttonhole or one in which stitches overlap.
5. The adjustable stop mounted on the travelling assembly engages the tripping lever to terminate the formation of a buttonhole.
6. The operator can precisely position the stop to define the closure point and prevent the formation of an open buttonhole or one in which stitches overlap.
7. The device can be used to sew buttonholes in different types of materials, including different fabrics, without the need for adjustments in the spring arrangement or spring stiffness.

1. The invention is a fabric treatment apparatus for treating dyed or printed textiles with a liquid solution.
2. The apparatus comprises a conveyor, a liquid applicator, a suction device, and a dwell stretch.
3. The conveyor includes an endless sieve belt for transporting the textile web along a predetermined substantially horizontal path.
4. The applicator is disposed at a first station along a path for applying the liquid to the web during motion thereof along the path.
5. The suction device is disposed at a second station along the path at a point downstream of the first station for removing the liquid from the web by a suction process during motion of the web along the path.
6. The dwell stretch is disposed between the applicator and the suction device for conducting the textile web in a spread-out condition and in a single layer through at least one dwell loop.
7. The dwell stretch device is formed by an air pass, wherein the textile web is completely free of support or guiding elements at least along major portions of the dwell stretch or loop and is accordingly accessible to the atmosphere at all sides.

The present invention provides an automatic quilting machine for sewing individualized patterns into large fabrics such as bedspread or quilt. The machine includes a separate process controller to control the table movement and sewing functions, allowing reprogramming of individualized patterns independently. The system also includes a reprogrammable computer to control the sewing needle and table movement, enabling precise stitching and pattern duplication. The key features include independent computer control for X-Y movement and sewing functions, and the ability to trace and modify patterns independently. The invention simplifies reprogramming of computer-controlled sewing machines by allowing reprogramming of individualized patterns without reprogramming the entire system.

The method involves providing a first precursor web comprising a fibrous matrix and a second precursor web comprising a second matrix, and between the first and second precursor webs, a fluid-pervious support layer or scrim is interposed and subjected to hydroentanglement on a moveable imaging surface having a three-dimensional image transfer device.

Summary 1: The invention is a sewing machine with a guide chute for a strip of material overlies the bed plate over which a workpiece material is fed. A stop is arranged in the feed path of the strip for contacting and stopping the feeding thereof which is displaceable out of the path and connectable by control means to the sewing machine for controlling the operation of the sewing machine in accordance with the position of the stop and the strip material.
Summary 2: The invention includes a control setup for feeding strip materials to a workpiece which is simple in design, rugged in construction and economical to manufacture.

Summary 1: The present invention provides a connective knitting method of two tape-shaped knit pieces, which is employed in a knitting procedure of a tape-shaped knit piece and a tape-shaped knit fabric knitted thereby. The method comprises steps of knitting two tape-shaped knit pieces by a flat knitting machine possessing at least a pair of front and rear needle beds, either or both of which are composed movably in a longitudinal direction, the two tape-shaped knit pieces being positioned with a boundary between them in a longitudinal direction on either of the front and the rear needle beds; overlaying symmetrical loops of the final course of both the knit pieces across the boundary and binding off the overlaid symmetrical loops gradually; thus repeating the latter step by a proper number of times depending on the width of two tape-shaped knit pieces until the two pieces are connected by the knitting machine. 

Summary 2: The invention also provides a connective knitting method having the end portions linked in a knitted state, which is employed in a knitting procedure of a tape-shaped knit fabric and a tape-shaped knit piece. The method comprises steps of knitting two tape-shaped knit pieces by a flat knitting machine possessing at least a pair of front and rear needle beds, either or both of which are composed movably in a longitudinal direction, the two tape-shaped knit pieces being positioned with a boundary between them in a longitudinal direction on either of the front and the rear needle beds; overlaying symmetrical loops of the final course of both the knit pieces across the boundary and binding off the overlaid symmetrical loops gradually; thus repeating the latter step by a proper number of times depending on the width of two tape-shaped knit pieces until the two pieces are connected by the knitting machine.

1. The invention provides a traction element, a production line for embedding at least one stranded cable in a flexible thermoplastic plastics material, and a method for embedding at least one stranded cable in a flexible thermoplastic plastics material.
2. The traction element comprises a core strand of each stranded cable, at least six peripheral strand cords wound around a central strand cord designated a core strand, and a flexible thermoplastic plastics material layer sheathing the core strands.
3. The strands are coated with a coating prior to stranding to increase flexibility and improve adhesion.
4. The strands are sheathed in a flexible thermoplastic plastics material layer, and the outer surface remains bare.
5. The strands are preferably embedded in a plastics material jacket made of polyurethane.
6. The traction element is produced by extruding a wire or thread guide and matrix, and sheathing the stranded cables with a plastics material jacket.
7. The method for embedding at least one stranded cable in a flexible thermoplastic plastics material includes preheating the plastics material jacket to a temperature of about ±20°C of the melting temperature of the flexible thermoplastic plastics material sheathing the core strands and sheathed in the extruder, and degreasing or coating the free surface of the stranded cables with an adhesion promoting layer and preheating the plastics material sheathing and the stranded cables to about ±20°C of the melting temperature of the liquefied plastics material.
8. The traction element is suitable for lifting and pulling loads when the traction element is deflected once or repeatedly and/or stored on a coiler.
9. The traction element is particularly suitable for the lifting and pulling of loads when the traction element is deflected once or repeatedly and/or stored on a coiler.
10. The traction element is suitable for the lifting and pulling of loads when the traction element is deflected once or repeatedly and/or stored on a coiler.

<summary>Summary of the Invention</summary>

The invention provides a lockstitch sewing machine with a rotary hook arrangement that prevents the bobbin housing from rotating with the hook body. The rotary hook includes a bobbin housing, a bobbin capsule carrier, and a spring-loaded holding finger. The spring-loaded holding finger is arranged on the bobbin capsule carrier and engages with a cutout in the bobbin capsule. The cutout is located at a distance before the holding finger in the direction of hook rotation. The spring-loaded holding finger is approximately centered between the two cams when the sewing machine is running, so that a thread passage gap is formed on both sides of the holding finger. During the looping around the bobbin housing, the spring-loaded holding finger is bent back briefly by the needle thread loop, which causes it to move through the rear and front thread passage gaps without using a capsule release device and without having to rotate the bobbin housing. During the pulling back of the needle thread loop, the spring-loaded holding finger is simply bent back by the needle thread. The spring-loaded holding finger offers not appreciable resistance if the spring force is rated correctly. The rotary hook is particularly useful for lockstitch sewing machines with a bobbin housing that is rotatable.

1. The invention provides methods for producing silicon-based nanowire/fiber composites and thin films using liquid silane inks.
2. The methods include electrospinning as an illustration, producing nanowire materials from four-component and five-component liquid silane inks, and using these materials to produce anode materials for lithium ion batteries.
3. The electrospinning methods are adapted from the invention and can be used to produce silicon-based nanowires and films.
4. The invention also provides liquid silane electro-spinning inks that include accelerants for increased setting or curing times.
5. The invention provides methods for producing polysilane nanowires and materials, and a method for continuous production of nanofiber strands and coated nanofiber strands.

<summary> 
  1. The present invention provides an arrangement for the control of thread tension in a spool creel, comprising a plurality of controllers that are simultaneously settable by fluid pressure. Each controller is coupled to a different corresponding one of the spool holders, and each controller has a brake rotor and an adjustable, tension responsive braking element coupled to the brake rotor. The arrangement also has a tensioning lever coupled to the braking element for biasing it. The tensioning lever has a roller adapted to engage and be biased by the threads, and this tensioning lever is operable to occupy an angular position dependent upon thread tension and weight. 
  2. The present invention also provides an alternate embodiment of the arrangement, wherein the brake shoe is provided to a further rotating braking surface, and the brake drum is applied only under higher fluid pressures to a further braking surface, which can cause the braking to occur rather rapidly at the shut down of the warping machine. 
  3. The present invention further provides a magnetic system for controlling the braking force, comprising a magnetic system 27 that surrounds braking disc 28, which is attached to brake drum 4 and is made from electrically conductive material, suitably aluminum. The magnetic system 27 comprises a U-shaped carrier 30 with two legs 31 and 32, and the legs 32 carry a permanent magnet 33. 
  4. The present invention also provides a pneumatic biasing arrangement for controlling the tensioning lever, comprising a fixedly supported cylinder 14 and a piston 15 (a piston and cylinder assembly) which is connected to the tensioning lever 8 by means of a hinge pin 16. The working magnitude of pressure may lie, for example, in the order or magnitude of two bars in order to support the operation of the mass of tensioning lever 8. When the working pressure of conduit system 21 is increased, the thread tension in the entire creel is raised. 
</summary>

1. The present invention provides a low-cost, durable sewing machine detector that minimizes stress on optical fibers and reduces static noise due to vibration.  
2. The detector includes a thin, compact detecting section with a thinner and more compact detecting section, and a thinner and more compact optical fiber supporter.

Summary 1: The present invention provides a simplified process for the continuous production of viscose rayon yarns with a high degree of whiteness, which can be achieved by reducing the space take-up of the spinning machines and speeding up the coagulation process. The process involves completing the coagulation, washing, drying, and possibly finishing the yarn, with the goal of obtaining a high degree of whiteness through various treatments. The invention also includes the use of weakly acid exchange resins to obtain water with a pH between 4.0 and 5.5, which is suitable for washing under the specified conditions. The summary ends with a comparison of the traditional process and the simplified process, highlighting the advantages of the simplified process in terms of reducing the number of treatments and economizing on spinning speeds.

1. The invention involves a small deaeration tank with an inlet pipe, an outlet, and a tangential swirl inducing inlet pipe. The tank has an exterior diameter of 106.68 cm and a height of 211.46 cm.
2. The tank is cylindrical with an open top and a flat bottom. The tank has an exterior diameter of 10.16 cm and a nominal height of 0.8 cm.
3. The inlet pipe has a center line between the upper surface of the slurry and the top edge of the tank, and extends across the interior of the tank a distance greater than 0.5 cm.
4. The outlet pipe has an outside diameter of 10.16 cm and a center line located between 0.15 cm and 0.4 cm below the outside of the tank.
5. The filtrate from the pulp mat enters the tank through the filtrate swirler inlet, which has a vertical center line that is between the bottom of the tank and the surface of the slurry.
6. The filtrate swirl inlet is located from the bottom of the tank a distance equal to 10-25% of the height of the tank, and is placed in the same vertical plane as the center line of the outlet pipe.

1. The invention improves upon the existing art by providing biomimetic tendon-reinforced (BTR) composite structures with improved properties, including a very high out-plane stiffness and strength-to-weight ratio.
2. A basic structure comprises a plurality of spaced-apart stuffer members, each having a first end and a second end defining a length. A plurality of tendon elements interconnect with the first and second ends of the stuffer members in alternating fashion, such that the tendon elements criss-cross each other between the stuffer members.
3. The stuffer members may be substantially parallel to one another and of equal or varying lengths. Alternatively, the stuffer members may be aligned along lines extending radially outwardly from a common center point (or multiple common center points, or without any common center point). The first and second panels may or may not be equidistant from one another. One of the panels may have a convex outer surface, with the other panel having a concave outer surface. Alternatively, both of the panels may have convex or concave outer surfaces.
4. The tendon elements may be made of carbon fibers, nylon, Kevlar, glass fibers, plant (botanic) fibers (e.g. hemp, flax), metal wires or other suitable materials. The stuffer members are preferably rigid, semi-rigid, or with desired flexibility, and may be solid or hollow components made of metal, ceramic or plastic.
5. The tendon elements may be tied or otherwise attached to one another where they criss-cross, thereby forming joints. If the stuffer members are tubes, the tendon elements may be oriented through the tubes. Alternatively, the tendon elements may be provided in the form of bent wires, each with a first bent end inserted into the first end of a stuffer member and a second bent end inserted into the second end of a different member.
6. Both linear and planar structures may be constructed according to the invention. For example, the stuffer members may be arranged in a two-dimensional plane, with the structure further including a panel bonded to one or both of the surfaces forming an I-beam structure. Alternatively, the stuffer members may be arranged in a two-dimensional array such that the ends of the members collectively define an upper and lower surface to which the panels are bonded or attached.

1. The present invention proposes a bedroom cabinet with a floor area at least approximately equal to an area of a bed, a height such that a user can erect the upper half of his body on the bed, and a circumference completely shut off from the outside except a doorway.

2. The invention provides a method and apparatus for recovery of crude oil from oil-bearing soils and rock formations using pulsed power electrohydraulic and electromagnetic discharges in wells producing acoustic and coupled electromagnetic-acoustic vibrations.

Summary 1: The present disclosure provides a splice for a soil reinforcing element, including a first wave plate defining one or more first transverse protrusions configured to receive and seat a corresponding number of transverse wires of the soil reinforcing element, and a second wave plate defining one or more second transverse protrusions configured to receive and seat a corresponding number of transverse wires of a grid-strip. The splice further includes a first perforation defined in the first wave plate and a second perforation defined in the second wave plate, and a connective device extensible through the first perforation and the second perforation to couple the first wave plate to the second wave plate, wherein a portion of longitudinal wires of the soil reinforcing element and a portion of longitudinal wires of the grid-strip are interposed between the first and second wave plates and are thereby prevented from removal. 

Summary 2: The present disclosure also provides a composite soil reinforcing element, including a soil reinforcing element having a first plurality of transverse wires coupled to at least two longitudinal wires, the soil reinforcing element having a wall end and a reinforcing end, a grid-strip having a second plurality of transverse wires coupled to at least two longitudinal wires, the grid-strip having a splicing end, and a splice configured to couple the reinforcing end of the soil reinforcing element to the splicing end of the grid-strip. The splice includes a first wave plate defining one or more first transverse protrusions configured to receive and seat a corresponding number of the first plurality of transverse wires of the soil reinforcing element, and a second wave plate defining one or more second transverse protrusions configured to receive and seat a corresponding number of the second plurality of transverse wires of the grid-strip. The splice for the composite soil reinforcing element further includes a first perforation defined on the first wave plate and a second perforation defined on the second wave plate, and a first connective device extensible through the first perforation and the second perforation to couple the first wave plate to the second wave plate and clamp down on the at least two longitudinal wires of the soil reinforcing element and the at least two longitudinal wires of the grid-strip.
